titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Rebecca West Collection
titlestmt.author: by Diane J. Ducharme

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday February 9, 2019 at 04:04
profiledesc.descrules: translation missing: en.enumerations.resource_finding_aid_description_rules.beinecke manuscript unit archival processing manual

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection contains letters to and from West, including extensive correspondences with Emanie Sachs Arling and Doris Stevens, as well as letters from Norman Mackenzie, Sara Tugander Melville, Jonathan Mitchell, Harold F. Rubinstein, and Reginald Turner; miscellaneous writings by West; and correspondence and memorabilia of West assembled by Gordon S. Haight.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This listing encompasses accessions of single manuscripts and small groups of manuscripts pertaining to Rebecca West acquired by gift and purchase from various sources by the Beinecke Library from 1960 to the present. Provenance has been noted briefly on the inital folder of each accession; for further information, see the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Rebecca West Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Rebecca West Collection. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Restricted Fragile Papers in Box 11 may only be consulted with permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies for reference use have been substituted in the main files.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This register is updated periodically. For information on material added to the collection since the last update, please consult the Public Services Desk.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For the papers donated by Rebecca West to Yale University in 1959, see GEN MSS 105, Rebecca West Papers; for related West material, see GEN MSS 240, G. Evelyn Hutchinson Papers Relating to Rebecca West.

bioghist.head: REBECCA WEST 1892-1983
bioghist.p: Rebecca West is the pseudonym of Cicely Isabel Fairfield, British journalist and novelist. Her major works include Black Lamb and Grey Falcon (1942), a study of Yugoslavia; A Train of Powder (1955), reports on the Nuremberg Trials; and The Meaning of Treason (1949), on the trial of William Joyce, who broadcast for Nazi Germany as Lord Haw-Haw. Among her novels are The Return of the Soldier (1918) , The Fountain Overflows (1957), and The Birds Fall Down (1966). She was created Dame of the British Empire in 1959.
West's decade-long relationship with H. G. Wells produced one son, Anthony Panther West, born in 1914. In 1930 West married the banker Henry Andrews, who died in 1968.
For further information consult the Dictionary of National Biography .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rebecca West Collection spans the dates 1913-1984 and is organized in four series. Series I, Correspondence , consists of letters to and from Rebecca West and is alphabetically arranged by name of correspondent. Series II, Writings , is organized in three subseries: Books, Articles, and Writings of Others. Series III, Rebecca West Papers of Gordon S. Haight , is organized in three subseries: Correspondence, Writings, and Other Papers. Materials acquired since September 1996 are located in Series IV, Additions since September 1996 , and are listed in accession order.

Series I, Correspondence
, contains mainly letters by West herself, in some cases donated by their recipients at West's request. Correspondents include Romney Brent, Henry James Forman, A. S. Frere, Lady Elizabeth Iddesleigh, Norman Mackenzie, C. K. Ogden, and Reginald Turner. West's letters to Sara Tugander Melville describe her daily life during the period following the birth of Anthony West and her travels to Italy and America during the 1920s. West's correspondence with Gregg T. Sinclair, begun when Sinclair sent her a fan letter about The Judge , documents her interest in visiting the Sinclairs in Japan and later in America.

The two extensive correspondences in the collection are those of Emanie Sachs Arling and Doris Stevens, both of whom West met during her first American lecture tour in 1923-24. West's letters to both women contain much information about her personal life, such as her health, her travels, life at Ibstone House with Henry Andrews, and her relations with family members. West's view of the troubled relationship between her and her son Anthony is particularly well documented, including her reaction to the publication of Heritage and to Anthony's divorce from his first wife and relocation to America. In addition, the correspondence with Stevens reflects West's involvement in the controversies surrounding Joseph McCarthy and the American anti-Communist movement.

Series II, Writings
, is divided into three subseries: Books, Articles, and Writings of Others. Books includes corrected galleys for The Birds Fall Down and The Thinking Reed , while Articles contains documentation of West's famous series "Behind the Witch-Hunts," including typescripts, clippings, and letters to the editor of the London Times concerning the series. Folder 172 contains clippings of articles by and about West's American lecture tour that appeared in the Japan Advertiser .

Series III, Rebecca West Papers of Gordon Haight
, contains correspondence from West and Henry Andrews to Haight, who was a member of the Department of English at Yale during West's visits to the university. There are also a typescript photocopy of Haight's response to Anthony West's portrait of West in Aspects of a Life , newspaper clippings, photographs, and other memorabilia.

Series IV, Additions Since September 1996
, contains recent acquisitions arranged in accession order.

Oversize
contains two items from Series II. Box 11,
Restricted Fragile Papers
, contains fragile originals from Series I-III.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Series II, Writings , is organized into three
subseries. Books and Articles are arranged
alphabetically by title. Writings of Others
is arranged alphabetically by name of author.

did.unittitle: Letters to the Editor of the Times concerning the article
Newspaper clipping from the New York Herald-Tribune
Typescript carbon, inscribed "To Gregg and Marjorie Sinclair, Henry M. Andrews, Rebecca West...July 1, 1956."
Rebecca West Papers of Gordon Haight

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Series III, Rebecca West Papers of Gordon
Haight, is organized into three subseries.
Correspondence is divided into Rebecca West
Correspondence, Henry Andrews Correspondence,
and G. Evelyn Hutchinson Correspondence. Each
is chronologically arranged. Writings and Other
Papers are arranged alphabetically by title or
type of material.

did.unittitle: Photograph and slides of West and Henry Andrews
Place cards for the publication dinner for H. G. Wells and Rebecca West by Gordon N. Ray

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Oversize contains two items from Series II.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

did.unittitle: Letters : various places, to [Doctor] Bethel Solomon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
7 items.
4 ALS, 1 APcS and 2 TLS discussing
West's health, personal news, and
her reaction to Anthony West's
Mortal Wounds and George Painter's
biography of Proust.
With: holograph manuscript of notes
on sightseeing possibilities in
Mexico (written for Solomon).
Gift, 1999.

did.unittitle: Letters : various places, to Charles Curran

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
10 items.
8 TLS and 2 ALS mainly discussing
her political views, particularly
on John Amery, William Joyce, and
the English and American Communist
Parties. An undated TLS offers her
highly negative opinion of the
"solemn dirt" of A Streetcar Named
Desire. Purchase, 1999.

did.unittitle: Letter : Ibstone House, to Edward H. Pearson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 item (2 L.) ; 21 cm.
TLS containing biographical
information, including West's comments
on her parents, and discussion of
"War Brides" article.
With: envelope.
Purchase, 2000.

did.unittitle: Letter : Ibstone House, to Fanny C. Goldstein

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 item (1 L.) ; 18 cm.
ALS responding angrily to
Goldstein's "cruel and insolent"
letter and defending herself
forcefully against the charge
of anti-Semitism in "two books
of mine....Please read nothing else
of mine."
With: envelope.
Purchase, 2000.

did.unittitle: Letter : Ibstone House, to Lewis Mumford

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 item (1 L.) ; 30 cm.
TLS commenting on an article by
Mumford in the 1968 Jul 6 New
Yorker. West talks about the
changing usage of footpaths,
her love of walking and the country,
and the relocation of tradesmen
from London to "country places."
Salutation reads: "Dear Mr. Muford."
Purchase, 2000.

did.unittitle: Photograph : Alex. Ayton, 42 and 43 Bruntsfield Place, Edinburgh

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 item.
Class portrait of class at George
Watson's Ladies' Seminary, George
Square. Cicely Fairfield in top
row, third from left.
C. G. MacDonald in third row,
sixth from left.
Accompanied by: clipping,
1996 Apr 15.
Gift, 1997.

did.unittitle: Letter : 15, Orchard Court, Portman Square, W.1 [London], to [Betty] Ross

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 item (1 L.) ; 20 cm.
TLS inviting her for a visit and
mentioning photographs.
Purchase, 2001.

did.unittitle: Letter : 15, Orchard Court, Portman Square, W.1 [London], to A. P. Herbert

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 item (1 L.) ; 20 cm.
TLS complimenting Herbert on an
article exposing coroners.
Purchase, 2003.

did.unittitle: Letter : 48 Kingston House North, to Mr. Dosse

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
